content: Well it looks as though longtime RINO Arlen Specter has finally decided to be honest and has announced that he'll run as a Democrat in 2010. +http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/28/source-specter-intends-switch-political-parties/ (from the article) RNC Chair Michael Steele on Specter's ship-jumping: Republican National Committee Chairman Michael Steele said some Republicans are happy about this, but he isn't. "Let's be honest -- Sen. Specter didn't leave the GOP based on principles of any kind," he said in a statement. "He left to further his personal political interests because he knew that he was going to lose a Republican primary due to his left-wing voting record. "Republicans look forward to beating Sen. Specter in 2010, assuming the Democrats don't do it first." As for me, I'm glad that Specter will no longer be a closet Democrat occupying a Republican seat in the Senate. Like Michael Steele, I look forward to Specter's defeat in the 2010 elections.

"Let's be honest -- Sen. Specter didn't leave the GOP based on principles of any kind," he said in a statement. "He left to further his personal political interests because he knew that he was going to lose a Republican primary due to his left-wing voting record. "Republicans look forward to beating Sen. Specter in 2010, assuming the Democrats don't do it first." As for me, I'm glad that Specter will no longer be a closet Democrat occupying a Republican seat in the Senate. Like Michael Steele, I look forward to Specter's defeat in the 2010 elections.

content: Well it looks as though longtime RINO Arlen Specter has finally decided to be honest and has announced that he'll run as a Democrat in 2010. +http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/28/source-specter-intends-switch-political-parties/ (from the article) RNC Chair Michael Steele on Specter's ship-jumping: Republican National Committee Chairman Michael Steele said some Republicans are happy about this, but he isn't. "Let's be honest -- Sen. Specter didn't leave the GOP based on principles of any kind," he said in a statement. "He left to further his personal political interests because he knew that he was going to lose a Republican primary due to his left-wing voting record. "Republicans look forward to beating Sen. Specter in 2010, assuming the Democrats don't do it first." As for me, I'm glad that Specter will no longer be a closet Democrat occupying a Republican seat in the Senate. Like Michael Steele, I look forward to Specter's defeat in the 2010 elections.

content: quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: ..WE NEED TERM LIMITS!! I absolutely agree with that. Term limits for every office in the land is the #1 change that needs to be made in order to start rooting out the cancerous corruption that is so manifestly obvious in DC. Serving as a representative in government was meant to be a temporary sacrifice, not as a way for a citizen to elevate himself above his fellow citizens and lord over them for decades, (all while abusing his power to enrich himself and his favored special interest groups). The very concept of a "career politician" would have been dispicable and uncacceptable to the Founders. Limiting Congressmen and Senators to 2 terms would go a long, long way toward restoring the proper role of these positions, i.e. as representatives of the people who elected them, with their concerns in mind, rather than these politicians constantly scheming as to how to get re-elected again and again and expand their own power.

content: Well it looks as though longtime RINO Arlen Specter has finally decided to be honest and has announced that he'll run as a Democrat in 2010. +http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/28/source-specter-intends-switch-political-parties/ (from the article) RNC Chair Michael Steele on Specter's ship-jumping: Republican National Committee Chairman Michael Steele said some Republicans are happy about this, but he isn't. "Let's be honest -- Sen. Specter didn't leave the GOP based on principles of any kind," he said in a statement. "He left to further his personal political interests because he knew that he was going to lose a Republican primary due to his left-wing voting record. "Republicans look forward to beating Sen. Specter in 2010, assuming the Democrats don't do it first." As for me, I'm glad that Specter will no longer be a closet Democrat occupying a Republican seat in the Senate. Like Michael Steele, I look forward to Specter's defeat in the 2010 elections.

content: quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: ..WE NEED TERM LIMITS!! I absolutely agree with that. Term limits for every office in the land is the #1 change that needs to be made in order to start rooting out the cancerous corruption that is so manifestly obvious in DC. Serving as a representative in government was meant to be a temporary sacrifice, not as a way for a citizen to elevate himself above his fellow citizens and lord over them for decades, (all while abusing his power to enrich himself and his favored special interest groups). The very concept of a "career politician" would have been dispicable and uncacceptable to the Founders. Limiting Congressmen and Senators to 2 terms would go a long, long way toward restoring the proper role of these positions, i.e. as representatives of the people who elected them, with their concerns in mind, rather than these politicians constantly scheming as to how to get re-elected again and again and expand their own power.
